STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
April 20, 2023
Sara Miller
CHILD & FAMILY SERVICES OF THE UPPER PENINSULA
706 CHIPPEWA SQ,
MARQUETTE, MI, 49855-4834
Re: License #: CB520201043
Dear Ms. Miller:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
April 3, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Kari Muntean, Area Manager, at 734-395-0920.
Sincerely,
Licensing Consultant
enclosure
2

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement
(1) An agency shall have a written foster
parent/agency agreement signed by the foster parent
and the agency before initially certifying a foster
home for licensure.
Three foster home files were reviewed.One of three files did not have a current
signed parent/agency agreement. The last signed agreement was dated April 24,
2021.
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified
by another agency or tribe, the agency shall have a
record containing all of the following documents:
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement
signed by the foster parent and the borrowing
agency.
One borrowed home file was reviewed. The file did not contain a parent/agency
agreement.
2

CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified
by another agency or tribe, the agency shall have a
record containing all of the following documents:
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has
received orientation to the policies of the borrowing
agency.
One borrowed home file was reviewed. The file lacked documentation that the foster
parent received orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker. • Supervisor. • Second line supervisor,
when siblings in care are placed apart. • Parents who
are a member of a participating household. • Youth
ages 14 and older. • Foster parents, relative
caregivers, and unrelated court ordered caregivers.
Three files and 10 treatment plans were reviewed. Three of ten treatment plans
lacked signatures, or the signatures were late. One treatment plan, dated November
23, 2022, did not document signatures. A second treatment plan, dated August 25,
2022, did not document signatures. A third treatment plan, dated November 30,
2022, documented a late signature. The foster parent signed the plan on January
18, 2023.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date. Note: This FTM may be combined with
the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM. Updated Case Plan
(USP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
due date. Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) -
within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is used
to capture family demographics, FTM logistical
3

information, needs, strengths, action steps, safety
concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the
FTM. The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report,
must be completed for every FTM.
Three foster care files and 10 FTM’s were reviewed. Four of 10 FTM’s either lacked
a DHS 1105, or occurred more than 30 days from the service plan due date, or did
not occur at a placement change. A FTM conducted on November 23, 2022, did not
have a DHS-1105 documented for the FTM. A FTM dated January 5, 2023.
occurred more than 30 days from the USP dated February 22, 2023. A FTM dated
December 6, 2022, occurred more than 30 days from the USP dated January 9,
2023. There was no FTM for an October 31, 2022, placement change.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical assistance was not required at this time.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not requested or offered at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) dated April
14, 2022, in response to those rule violations established during the renewal
inspection completed on March 31, 2022. The rule violations were as follows: R
400.12310 (4), R 400.12324 (4)(c), R 400.12324 (8), R 400.12326 (1) (h), R
400.12327 (1)(a), R 400.12327 (1)(b), R 400.12327 (6)(a), R400.12327 (6)(b), and
R 400.12405 (3)(f), The agency CAP was sucessful in preventing repeat
violations as none were established during the current interim inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrators annual assessment was thorough and addressed the
rule violations established during the renewal audit completed on March 21, 2022.
The assessment also addressed barriers and systemic factors that have impacted
compliance with rules, policy, and ISEP.
4

Financial Overview
The agency provided copies of the annual budget for review and the agency is
financially viable for the foster care and adoption programs. At the time of the
onsite visit on March 14, 2023, the agency presented for my review an annual
certified public accountant audit of the agency.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviewed reported feeling very supported by their Chief Administrator who
provides direct supervision. Staff reported that they feel they are part of a
supportive team that pulls together to help each other when needed.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency has appropriate office space and is well equipped and organized.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The CPA Analyst generated a safety alert on February 1, 2023, regarding the lack of
smoke alarms in a foster home basement and main floor. The agency was contacted on
the same day and initiated a special evaluation. Alarms were installed on February 2,
2023, and photographs of the installed alarms were provided. The safety alert was
resolved February 2, 2023.
The CPA Analyst reported that in her interviews with foster parents and relatives they
reported that they felt supported by the agency.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
April 18, 2023
________________________________________
Douglas W Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
April 20, 2023
________________________________________
Kari Muntean Date
Area Manager
